options.text: What can I build with PyGame?

pygamePossibilities.speaker: Pixel
pygamePossibilities.text: EVERYTHING! Platformers, RPGs, puzzle games, racing games... if you can imagine it, PyGame can build it!
pygamePossibilities.followUp: Famous games like Frets on Fire were made with PyGame! Let's start your journey!

pygameBasics.speaker: Pixel
pygameBasics.text: Every PyGame program starts the same way - initialize, create a window, and run a game loop!
pygameBasics.codeExample:
import pygame

# Initialize PyGame
pygame.init()

# Create game window
screen = pygame.display.set_mode((800, 600))
pygame.display.set_caption('My First Game!')

# Game loop
running = True
clock = pygame.time.Clock()

while running:
    # Handle events
    for event in pygame.event.get():
        if event.type == pygame.QUIT:
            running = False
    
    # Fill screen with color (R, G, B)
    screen.fill((0, 128, 255))  # Sky blue!
    
    # Update display
    pygame.display.flip()
    clock.tick(60)  # 60 FPS

pygame.quit()
pygameBasics.followUp: This is your game's heartbeat - the loop that keeps everything running!

gameLoopExplained.speaker: Pixel
gameLoopExplained.text: The game loop is like your game's heartbeat - it runs 60 times per second!

drawingShapes.speaker: Pixel
drawingShapes.text: PyGame can draw shapes, images, and text! Let's start with colorful shapes!
drawingShapes.codeExample:
import pygame
pygame.init()

screen = pygame.display.set_mode((800, 600))
running = True
clock = pygame.time.Clock()

# Colors (R, G, B)
WHITE = (255, 255, 255)
RED = (255, 0, 0)
GREEN = (0, 255, 0)
BLUE = (0, 0, 255)
YELLOW = (255, 255, 0)

while running:
    for event in pygame.event.get():
        if event.type == pygame.QUIT:
            running = False
    
    screen.fill(WHITE)
    
    # Draw shapes!
    pygame.draw.circle(screen, RED, (400, 300), 50)  # Circle
    pygame.draw.rect(screen, BLUE, (100, 100, 200, 150))  # Rectangle
    pygame.draw.line(screen, GREEN, (0, 0), (800, 600), 5)  # Line
    
    # Draw filled shapes
    pygame.draw.circle(screen, YELLOW, (600, 100), 30)
    pygame.draw.polygon(screen, RED, [(300, 400), (400, 400), (350, 300)])
    
    pygame.display.flip()
    clock.tick(60)

pygame.quit()
drawingShapes.followUp: Shapes are the building blocks - combine them to create anything!

movement.speaker: Pixel
movement.text: Movement is just changing position over time - add to X to go right, subtract to go left!
movement.codeExample:
import pygame
pygame.init()

screen = pygame.display.set_mode((800, 600))
clock = pygame.time.Clock()

# Player position and speed
player_x = 400
player_y = 300
speed = 5

running = True
while running:
    for event in pygame.event.get():
        if event.type == pygame.QUIT:
            running = False
    
    # Get keyboard input
    keys = pygame.key.get_pressed()
    
    # Move based on keys
    if keys[pygame.K_LEFT]:
        player_x -= speed
    if keys[pygame.K_RIGHT]:
        player_x += speed
    if keys[pygame.K_UP]:
        player_y -= speed
    if keys[pygame.K_DOWN]:
        player_y += speed
    
    # Keep player on screen
    player_x = max(25, min(775, player_x))
    player_y = max(25, min(575, player_y))
    
    # Draw everything
    screen.fill((100, 100, 100))
    pygame.draw.circle(screen, (255, 255, 0), (player_x, player_y), 25)
    
    pygame.display.flip()
    clock.tick(60)
movement.followUp: Arrow keys control movement - you just made an interactive game!

sprites.speaker: Pixel
sprites.text: Sprites are game images - characters, items, backgrounds. PyGame makes them easy to use!
sprites.codeExample:
import pygame
pygame.init()

screen = pygame.display.set_mode((800, 600))
clock = pygame.time.Clock()

# Load an image (you'll need an image file!)
# player_image = pygame.image.load('player.png')
# For now, let's create a surface
player_image = pygame.Surface((50, 50))
player_image.fill((0, 255, 0))  # Green square as placeholder

class Player:
    def __init__(self, x, y):
        self.image = player_image
        self.rect = self.image.get_rect()
        self.rect.x = x
        self.rect.y = y
        self.speed = 5
    
    def update(self, keys):
        if keys[pygame.K_LEFT]:
            self.rect.x -= self.speed
        if keys[pygame.K_RIGHT]:
            self.rect.x += self.speed
    
    def draw(self, screen):
        screen.blit(self.image, self.rect)

# Create player
player = Player(400, 300)

running = True
while running:
    for event in pygame.event.get():
        if event.type == pygame.QUIT:
            running = False
    
    keys = pygame.key.get_pressed()
    player.update(keys)
    
    screen.fill((100, 100, 100))
    player.draw(screen)
    
    pygame.display.flip()
    clock.tick(60)
sprites.followUp: Sprites + Classes = organized, powerful game objects!

collisions.speaker: Pixel
collisions.text: Collisions detect when game objects touch - essential for gameplay!
collisions.codeExample:
import pygame
import random
pygame.init()

screen = pygame.display.set_mode((800, 600))
clock = pygame.time.Clock()

class GameObject:
    def __init__(self, x, y, width, height, color):
        self.rect = pygame.Rect(x, y, width, height)
        self.color = color
    
    def draw(self, screen):
        pygame.draw.rect(screen, self.color, self.rect)

# Create player and collectibles
player = GameObject(400, 300, 50, 50, (0, 255, 0))
coin = GameObject(200, 200, 30, 30, (255, 255, 0))
score = 0

font = pygame.font.Font(None, 36)

running = True
while running:
    for event in pygame.event.get():
        if event.type == pygame.QUIT:
            running = False
    
    # Move player
    keys = pygame.key.get_pressed()
    if keys[pygame.K_LEFT]: player.rect.x -= 5
    if keys[pygame.K_RIGHT]: player.rect.x += 5
    if keys[pygame.K_UP]: player.rect.y -= 5
    if keys[pygame.K_DOWN]: player.rect.y += 5
    
    # Check collision!
    if player.rect.colliderect(coin.rect):
        score += 10
        # Move coin to new position
        coin.rect.x = random.randint(0, 750)
        coin.rect.y = random.randint(0, 550)
    
    # Draw everything
    screen.fill((50, 50, 50))
    player.draw(screen)
    coin.draw(screen)
    
    # Draw score
    score_text = font.render(f'Score: {score}', True, (255, 255, 255))
    screen.blit(score_text, (10, 10))
    
    pygame.display.flip()
    clock.tick(60)
collisions.followUp: colliderect() checks if rectangles overlap - instant collision detection!

sound.speaker: Pixel
sound.text: Sound brings games to life! Music, effects, voices - PyGame handles it all!
sound.codeExample:
import pygame
pygame.init()
pygame.mixer.init()  # Initialize sound system

# Load sounds (you'll need sound files!)
# jump_sound = pygame.mixer.Sound('jump.wav')
# coin_sound = pygame.mixer.Sound('coin.wav')
# pygame.mixer.music.load('background_music.mp3')

# For demonstration, let's create beeps
screen = pygame.display.set_mode((800, 600))
clock = pygame.time.Clock()

# Play background music
# pygame.mixer.music.play(-1)  # -1 means loop forever

class Player:
    def __init__(self):
        self.x = 400
        self.y = 500
        self.jumping = False
        self.jump_speed = 0
    
    def jump(self):
        if not self.jumping:
            self.jumping = True
            self.jump_speed = -15
            # jump_sound.play()  # Play sound effect!
            print('Jump sound!')
    
    def update(self):
        if self.jumping:
            self.y += self.jump_speed
            self.jump_speed += 1  # Gravity
            if self.y >= 500:
                self.y = 500
                self.jumping = False

player = Player()

running = True
while running:
    for event in pygame.event.get():
        if event.type == pygame.QUIT:
            running = False
        if event.type == pygame.KEYDOWN:
            if event.key == pygame.K_SPACE:
                player.jump()
    
    player.update()
    
    screen.fill((135, 206, 235))  # Sky blue
    pygame.draw.circle(screen, (255, 100, 0), (int(player.x), int(player.y)), 25)
    pygame.draw.rect(screen, (100, 200, 100), (0, 525, 800, 75))  # Ground
    
    pygame.display.flip()
    clock.tick(60)
sound.followUp: Sound effects make actions feel real - every jump, hit, and victory!

options.text: How do I manage game states?

gameStates.speaker: Pixel
gameStates.text: Game states manage different screens - menu, playing, game over. Essential for complete games!
gameStates.codeExample:
import pygame
pygame.init()

screen = pygame.display.set_mode((800, 600))
clock = pygame.time.Clock()
font = pygame.font.Font(None, 74)
small_font = pygame.font.Font(None, 36)

# Game states
MENU = 'menu'
PLAYING = 'playing'
GAME_OVER = 'game_over'

current_state = MENU
score = 0

def draw_menu(screen):
    screen.fill((50, 50, 50))
    title = font.render('MY GAME', True, (255, 255, 255))
    start = small_font.render('Press SPACE to Start', True, (200, 200, 200))
    screen.blit(title, (250, 200))
    screen.blit(start, (250, 350))

def draw_game(screen):
    screen.fill((100, 150, 200))
    score_text = small_font.render(f'Score: {score}', True, (255, 255, 255))
    screen.blit(score_text, (10, 10))
    # Draw game objects here

def draw_game_over(screen):
    screen.fill((100, 0, 0))
    over = font.render('GAME OVER', True, (255, 255, 255))
    restart = small_font.render('Press R to Restart', True, (200, 200, 200))
    screen.blit(over, (200, 200))
    screen.blit(restart, (250, 350))

running = True
while running:
    for event in pygame.event.get():
        if event.type == pygame.QUIT:
            running = False
        if event.type == pygame.KEYDOWN:
            if current_state == MENU:
                if event.key == pygame.K_SPACE:
                    current_state = PLAYING
                    score = 0
            elif current_state == PLAYING:
                if event.key == pygame.K_ESCAPE:
                    current_state = GAME_OVER
            elif current_state == GAME_OVER:
                if event.key == pygame.K_r:
                    current_state = MENU
    
    # Draw based on state
    if current_state == MENU:
        draw_menu(screen)
    elif current_state == PLAYING:
        draw_game(screen)
        score += 1  # Simple score increase
        if score > 500:  # End game after score
            current_state = GAME_OVER
    elif current_state == GAME_OVER:
        draw_game_over(screen)
    
    pygame.display.flip()
    clock.tick(60)
gameStates.followUp: States let you build complete games with menus, levels, and endings!

miniProject.speaker: Pixel
miniProject.text: Let's combine everything into a mini game - Coin Collector!
miniProject.followUp: Use arrow keys to collect coins, avoid enemies, and get the high score!
miniProject.codeExample:
# COIN COLLECTOR GAME
import pygame
import random

pygame.init()
screen = pygame.display.set_mode((800, 600))
pygame.display.set_caption('Coin Collector!')
clock = pygame.time.Clock()
font = pygame.font.Font(None, 36)

# Game objects
player = pygame.Rect(400, 300, 40, 40)
coins = []
enemies = []
score = 0
game_over = False

# Create coins
for _ in range(5):
    coin = pygame.Rect(random.randint(0, 760), random.randint(0, 560), 20, 20)
    coins.append(coin)

# Create enemies
for _ in range(3):
    enemy = pygame.Rect(random.randint(0, 760), random.randint(0, 560), 30, 30)
    enemies.append(enemy)

running = True
while running:
    for event in pygame.event.get():
        if event.type == pygame.QUIT:
            running = False
    
    if not game_over:
        # Move player
        keys = pygame.key.get_pressed()
        if keys[pygame.K_LEFT]: player.x -= 5
        if keys[pygame.K_RIGHT]: player.x += 5
        if keys[pygame.K_UP]: player.y -= 5
        if keys[pygame.K_DOWN]: player.y += 5
        
        # Keep player on screen
        player.x = max(0, min(760, player.x))
        player.y = max(0, min(560, player.y))
        
        # Check coin collection
        for coin in coins[:]:
            if player.colliderect(coin):
                coins.remove(coin)
                score += 10
                # Spawn new coin
                new_coin = pygame.Rect(random.randint(0, 760), random.randint(0, 560), 20, 20)
                coins.append(new_coin)
        
        # Check enemy collision
        for enemy in enemies:
            if player.colliderect(enemy):
                game_over = True
        
        # Move enemies randomly
        for enemy in enemies:
            enemy.x += random.randint(-2, 2)
            enemy.y += random.randint(-2, 2)
            enemy.x = max(0, min(770, enemy.x))
            enemy.y = max(0, min(570, enemy.y))
    
    # Draw everything
    screen.fill((50, 50, 50))
    
    if not game_over:
        pygame.draw.rect(screen, (0, 255, 0), player)  # Player - green
        for coin in coins:
            pygame.draw.circle(screen, (255, 255, 0), coin.center, 10)  # Coins - yellow
        for enemy in enemies:
            pygame.draw.rect(screen, (255, 0, 0), enemy)  # Enemies - red
    else:
        game_over_text = font.render('GAME OVER!', True, (255, 255, 255))
        screen.blit(game_over_text, (300, 250))
    
    score_text = font.render(f'Score: {score}', True, (255, 255, 255))
    screen.blit(score_text, (10, 10))
    
    pygame.display.flip()
    clock.tick(60)

pygame.quit()
